Working with the Requirement Pane

When you click the Requirement tab, existing requirements display in the upper pane of the project view window. The Requirement menu item also becomes available on the menu bar.

All requirements shown in the upper pane:

  • Are attached to the folder selected from the application folder hierarchy.

  • Match the filter selected from the Filter drop-down list box.

  • Match the depth specified by the All Descendants button.

Choosing a Tree or List Format

When the Tree Display button is selected on the toolbar, each requirement appears as an expandable requirement tree, with the child requirements as its branches, on the upper pane. The tree displays the relationships between the requirement and its child requirements. It also allows you to move or share requirements. The tree format is the default format.

Clicking an unexpanded branch of a requirement tree expands it; clicking it again collapses it. Double-clicking a requirement expands or collapses its branches. Selecting Expand All and Collapse All from the Requirement menu or context menu completely expands or collapses all trees.

The tree format also uses special icons to show whether you have read the requirements for which you are responsible.

When the List Display button is selected on the toolbar, information in the upper pane appears in list format. No relationships among requirements are shown. However, the list format allows you to:

  • See the values of specific fields as columns of data. For example, you can view the status for each requirement.

  • Sort the requirements by any column header.

Using the Requirements Pane

From the Requirements pane, you can perform a variety of operations, including:

View unread items

In both tree and list format, requirements for which you are responsible but have not reviewed are shown in boldface type. The requirements in regular type are those that you have read or those for which you are not responsible.

View properties

To see the properties of a specific requirement, double-click it.

Identify deterred or rejected requirements

In list format, the icon that appears immediately before the Status column indicates whether the requirement has been deferred or rejected or not.

Review requirement priority level

In list format, the icon that appears with a requirement indicates its priority level. The priority level can be Essential, Desirable, or Useful. Each level is indicated by a specific icon.

Move requirements

In the tree format, you can move a requirement from one application folder to another by dragging it. You can also move requirements to other views or projects that use the same server configuration.

Share requirements

In the tree format, you can share a requirement in one application folder with another folder, by pressing Ctrl, then dragging the requirement to the second folder. You can also share requirements with other views or projects, as long as they use the same server configuration.

Filter data

In list format, you can rearrange requirement fields, show different fields, use group bands, and apply queries to the data in the list. You can also save operations on the data as a query or filter. To perform these actions from the context menu, right-click a column header to display the menu.

Sort requirements

In list format, you can click a requirement column header to perform a sort based on the value in that column. The sort is usually in ascending numeric or alphanumeric order, depending on the data. To change the sort order from ascending to descending (or vice versa), click the header a second time. A triangle indicating the direction of the sort appears on the header of the primary sort column.

Default columns on the requirement list are:

  • Number: Number that the application assigned to the requirement when it was first submitted.

  • Created By: Name of the user who created the requirement.

  • Created Time: Time at which the requirement was created.

  • Name: Name of the requirement.

  • Description: Purpose of the requirement.

  • Status: Indication of the requirement’s progress from submitted to rejected or completed, which is considered the requirement life cycle. The sort order for statuses is: Submitted, Pending, Accepted, Draft, Deferred, Review, Complete, ReadyForCCB (Change Control Board), Rejected, and Approved.

  • Locked By: Name of users who currently have an exclusive lock on the requirement.

  • Priority: Indicates the requirement’s importance. The sort order for priorities is: Unassigned, Essential, Useful, and Desirable.

Refresh view

Press Shift + F5 to refresh the entire view (all items on all tabs as well as the application folder hierarchy). Press F5 to refresh only the requirement pane. Press Ctrl + F5 to refresh the requirement pane and collapse all open groups simultaneously.
